description:
Cladophialophora carrionii CBS 160.54 is a species of dematiaceous (dark-pigmented) fungus that belongs to the genus Cladophialophora. This fungus is known to be a causative agent of chromoblastomycosis, a chronic and recurrent skin and subcutaneous tissue infection that primarily affects individuals in tropical and subtropical regions.

The key features of C. carrionii CBS 160.54 include:

1. Morphology: The fungus produces dark-colored, septate hyphae and conidiophores that bear clusters of brown, thick-walled, muriform (cross-walled) conidia, which are characteristic of the genus Cladophialophora.

2. Growth characteristics: C. carrionii CBS 160.54 is a slow-growing fungus that typically forms a velvety, olivaceous-brown to black colony on culture media, such as Sabouraud dextrose agar.

3. Genetic identification: The species can be identified through molecular techniques, such as DNA sequencing of the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region or other diagnostic gene markers.

4. Pathogenicity: C. carrionii CBS 160.54 is a recognized etiological agent of chromoblastomycosis, a chronic fungal infection that can lead to the development of verrucous, cauliflower-like lesions on the skin and subcutaneous tissues, primarily affecting the lower extremities.

This strain, CBS 160.54, was originally isolated from a case of chromoblastomycosis and is maintained in the Centraalbureau voor Schimmelcultures (CBS) culture collection, which serves as an important resource for the study and identification of medically relevant fungal species.
